53. Thompson, Rosanna (Mrs. William Maynard)
Edgeley, Sask Mar 18 1952.

The Sask Archives Office,
Box 100 Saskatoon Sask.

Dear Sirs:

You sent me the enclosed forms a year ago for my mother (who is an old timer) to fill out. I sent them to her but she was ill at the time and did not do it. Late last spring she came to visit me and we found she had cancer so she had an operation and was convalescing here all summer. I got the answers to the questions at times when she was able and this winter I forgot to send them to you until I heard your report on the News Commentary last night.

I am sorry to have neglected this as I consider it an important part of Saskatchewan's history and there are so few of the settlers of the 1880 decade left.

Mother was a small girl when she came West but since there were no schools then she was right at the helm of housekeeping from the start, though she does not remember so much about the marketing and prices of things until she grew up.

The Deaf man mentioned was a homeless man who dropped in, in Quebec and stayed for meals and then for days, and weeks, and finally just stayed with the family. They never knew his name or anything about him, but he stayed with them for 30 or 40 years and died when I was 17. The doctors told them he was probably born deaf and so had never learned to speak, as there were no special schools in those days.

Hoping this is not too late to be of use to you I remain

Yours Truly
Mrs J.R.Morrison, Box 12 Edgeley Sask.

12. WATER SUPPLY

There did you get water for drinking and for cooking? (well, river, slough, dugout). Dig a shallow well, beside a slough and the water filtered into it.

How was it brought to the house? (pail, barrel, tank) By, mail.

Regarding water supply, mention any changes which have taken place since you first started homesteading. Lay our dates there possible.

Dig a deeper well in 1987 and kept it clean. Refresh wells as needed.

One well dug with a well-digging drill 60 ft deep about 70 ft from house. The water had alkali and was unfit for use but game, meat and cream were lowered into the cold well a few feet from the water, and so it was our first fringe. We still get drinking water from a well about 100 yards from the house.

19. Were you ever reduced to almost starvation level living on one or two locally produced foods? Give details.

Never to near starvation level but we often had to live almost entirely on products of the farm, flour from our own sometimes proven meat, wild fruit, homestead vegetables, honey, eggs, milk, and butter. If they were scarce we had to make them do. But we never were hungry though living was monotonous sometimes.

19. Were you ever reduced to almost starvation level living on one or two locally produced foods? Give details.

At first almost everything was in paper bags, wooden boxes, tea in tins, lead containers, jars for sugar etc., appeared, and 100 lb. cotton bags for sugar etc. appeared.
20. In what ways do you see an improvement in the preparation of meals in the past? How much more time did you spend on meal preparation?

21. What did you begin to rely on prepared foods and processed foods instead of fresh ingredients? Give as many details as possible.

22. Please add other details from your early experiences of buying groceries and preparing meals. Include items not mentioned above, quality, methods of purchasing, prices, problems or shortages, and other details. Use back of page if more space is needed.

In 1983 my husband first came West and worked for his brother-in-law while there in the spring. He spent his spare time hunting wild duck eggs for the leader. There was plenty of all year and was a large item in helping provide fresh meat. Soon after he came West he saw the first skunks in the Okanagan valley but was afraid they might be poisonous until he saw birds and Indians eating them. They too were very welcome treat to one coming from the fruit farms of Quebec. We also found the valley a source of chokecherries, gooseberries, wild currants and hops for yeast. In fact we early learned to keep an eye open at all times for such things, as they were valuable as health foods (vitamins now-a-days).
20. Question any outstanding differences in the preparation of meals in the earliest days compared with today.

We still rely greatly on homegrown foods but we have them canned and frozen in a locker plant instead of salted and dried as in the past. Also, of course, we have a much greater variety of food now with modern vitamins and prepared foods which make the getting of meals much faster. One doesn't need to look so far ahead, and things are handier for emergencies.

21. When did you begin to rely on purchased foods and prepared foods instead of homemade and home preserved foods? (Give as many details and dates as possible).

After the town of Abernethy came within a mile of us in 1905 we gradually came to relying on quicker prepared foods, but I have only baked bread etc. since 1948. Mostly we see the difference in flavors and fresh winter vegetables and fruits which can be shipped in fresher with modern refrigeration. Before 1905 things had to be hauled 25 miles by buggy or wagon so we still lived on the farm as much as possible.

Before the town of Abernethy was built, in 1905, we made 2 or 3 trips by horse and buggy to Indian Head or Sintaluta each summer for groceries and in winter my husband laid in a stock of staples when he was hauling wheat to the same towns. Also the were rural "corners" called Saltoon and Chickney with grocery stores and a blacksmith shop.

The Post office was kept by a local farmer.

22. Please add other details from your early experiences of buying groceries and securing foods in other ways during pioneer days in Western Canada. Include items not mentioned above, quality, methods of merchandising, prices, problems of storage, shortages and other details. Use back of page if more space is needed.

In 1882 my husband first came West and worked for his brother-in-law. While there in the spring he spent his spare time hunting wild duck eggs for the larder. Game was plentiful all year, and was a large item in helping provide fresh meat.

Soon after he came West he saw the first saskatoons in the Qu'Appelle valley, but was afraid they might be poisonous until he saw birds and Indians eating them. They too were a very welcome treat to one coming from the fruit farms of Quebec.

We also found the valley a scourge of chokecherries, gooseberries, wild currants and hops for yeast. In fact we early learned to keep an eye open at all times for such things, as they were valuable as health foods (vitamins nowadays).
